poem:
### A Cage in Search

In the morning hush,
a cage roams freely,
through cold dawn mists,
seeking its prisoner.

Without bars,
the world is a quiet riddle,
a puzzle of open landscapes—
yawning fields and silent streets.

Who roams, who searches,
the cage or its prey?

In this space between dawn and dusk,
every fragment holds its own tale.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Kafka: Selected Stories, edited by Mark Harman review – the master who never wasted a word In the case, the singular case, of Franz Kafka, the law of diminishing returns might be applied in an adapted form: the more diminished the text, the richer the return. Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
